answers: Seven Dwarves [or Seven Dwarfs; prompt on "dwarfs" or "dwarves" by asking "how many?"]
parts: Identify these characters. In their most famous appearance, they save a girl from plots involving a huntsman and a corset and later place her in a glass coffin.
"Snow White and the Seven Dwarves" is one of the folk tales collected by this pair of German brothers in the 19th century.

This British-born author, who lives in Prague, adapted "Snow White" into her novel Boy, Snow, Bird. Answers to the question "Where is Miranda Silver?" are explored in her mystery novel White is for Witching.

answers: Blackfoot Confederacy [or Blackfeet or Niitsitapi or Siksikaitsitapi]
parts: The dispersal created the population of these wild horses in the American West, who lend their name to a car made by Ford.
This fierce Native American people's mastery of those horses enabled them to build a vast empire centered on present-day North Texas.

This other native nation, which at the time was pressured by European traders to move west from the Great Lakes, expanded into the territory of the Cree and Assiniboine by mastering the horses. They built a great confederacy in the upper Great Plains, spanning the present-day U.S. and Canada.
The workshop was hosted at this institution, whose longtime president John Kemeny invented the programming language BASIC.

The term "artificial intelligence" itself was coined around the time of the workshop by John McCarthy, who also invented this language which uses s-expressions to express both source code and data. Its name refers to "processing" certain data structures.
The workshop's other attendees included this "father of information theory," who created a form of entropy, denoted H, to characterize uncertainty in a random variable.

answers: Medina [or al-Madinah al-Munawwarah; or al-Madinah an-Nabi; accept Yathrib]
six [or sittah; accept the Six Books or al-Kutub as-Sittah; accept the Authentic Six or as-Sihah as-Sittah]
parts: Name this school of Islamic jurisprudence that's dominant in North and West Africa.
Malikis uniquely accept as a source of law the customs of this city, where the earliest Muslim community was established after Muhammad fled Mecca in the hijra.

Though only Malikis recognize the Muwatta of Malik, they also reject the Sunan of Ibn Majah, so they, like all Sunni madhhabs, have this many canonical hadith collections. This number is one (emphasize) fewer than the number of past imams recognized by Ismai'ilis.

answers: the sovereign [accept sovereignty; do not accept or prompt on "monarch" or "absolute monarch" or "king"]
parts: Give this specific term used in Leviathan to denote the single source into which the political power of a commonwealth should be invested.
In contrast to Hobbes, this philosopher suggested that the state of nature was preferable to rule by an arbitrary single sovereign in his Two Treatises of Government.
This German theorist coined the phrase "state of exception" to denote instances in which the sovereign should override the law for the public good. He also wrote "The Concept of the Political".
This author references Winnicott's theories of the "true" and "false" self throughout her graphic novels Are You My Mother? and Fun Home.
In her memoirs, Clare Winnicott mentions Donald's fervent reading of this author's works, such as To the Lighthouse, which Alison Bechdel also cites as a major influence.

In interviews, this woman and her wife Susie Orbach have discussed Winnicott's theories of creativity as a guiding influence. Winnicott's theory of trauma has been used to analyze this author's novel Oranges Are Not the Only Fruit.

Name these expressions. The integral from 0 to sin phi of (read slowly) "dt, over the square root of 1 minus t squared times 1 minus k squared t squared," is one of these expressions "of the first kind".
Carl Jacobi ("yah-KOH-bee") used a complete elliptic integral of the first kind to describe the motion of these objects, which consist of a bob suspended from a pivot.
The period of a physical pendulum is proportional to the square root of (emphasize) this quantity over m g times the length to the center of mass.

answers: Un Chien Andalou [or An Andalusian Dog]
parts: Name this 1929 film which features a shot that cuts from a close-up of a woman's eye, to a thin cloud passing over the moon, to a razor slicing open an eyeball.
Un Chien Andalou is one of the greatest films from this André Breton-led art movement, whose leading painters included René Magritte.

Though Germaine Dulac's The Seashell and the Clergyman is often considered the first proper Surrealist film, this director's short film Entr'acte features many Surrealist techniques and the music of Erik Satie. This director later made À Nous la Liberté.

answers: Great Mosque of Mecca [or Grand Mosque of Mecca, or al-Masjid al-Haram, or Forbidden Mosque, or Sacred Mosque; prompt on Great Mosque or Grand Mosque or mosque or masjid; do not accept or prompt on "Prophet's Mosque" or "al-Masjid al-Nabawi"]
parts: Name this building which was captured in 1979 by extremists under Juhayman al-Otaybi. Three GIGN members advised the Saudi government in retaking this building.
The day after the mosque's invasion, protesters burned down this city's U.S. embassy. It replaced Karachi as Pakistan's capital in 1961.

The Saudi king, Khalid, responded to the Grand Mosque siege by granting this body more authority over Saudi customs and law. In general, this Arabic word for "learned ones" collectively refers to Islamic religious experts.

answers: Central European University [or CEU; do not accept or prompt on "Central Europe University"]
parts: Name this political theorist who gave a pragmatic basis for rights in Human Rights as Politics and Idolatry. He later led Canada's Liberal Party for three years.
Ignatieff came to prominence with his documentary series Blood and Belonging, which he created for this non-Canadian public media organization which runs Channel One.

Ignatieff now serves as rector at this university, which moved from Budapest to Vienna in 2018 due to Viktor Orban's policies. This highly ranked university is logically named for its geographic location.
Name this composer of the Jewish Cycle, which contains an Ecclesiastes-inspired piece in which solo cello represents the title Biblical king.
This composer's Kaddish Symphony was inspired by the Jewish prayer for the dead. This prominent music educator was the first U.S. born conductor of the New York Philharmonic.
This composer wrote a work in Hebrew for four women's voices and orchestra titled Tehillim. Themes from his Jewish heritage feature prominently in his piece Different Trains.

answers: hominin footprints [accept Siwa footprints or Laetoli footprints; accept footsteps]
parts: Name these things. Site G in the Olduvai gorge preserves the "Laetoli" ones attributed to Australopithecus afarensis.
The Laetoli footprints were found by Mary, a social scientist with this surname; with her husband Louis, and her team, she discovered the "Lucy" skeleton.

This name identifies the person who left the oldest-known footprints of anatomically modern humans near Langebaan Lagoon. It also identifies a person whose mitochondrial DNA is ancestral to that of all modern humans.

answers: Phanariotes [or Fanariots or Fanarioti or Fenerliler] (They are named for the Fener quarter.)
parts: Give this term for the most prominent urban Greek families within the Ottoman empire, who were collectively named for the city quarter where many of them lived.
The Phanariotes were based in this city, whose Greek name was not officially changed to Istanbul until after the founding of the Turkish Republic.

The Phanariotes were regarded as the political heads of a millet of this name in the Ottoman Empire. This Turkish and Arabic term for the Byzantine empire also names a Seljuk sultanate founded by Malik Shah in 1075.

answers: Li Bai [or Li Po; prompt on Li]
Cixin Liu [or Liu Cixin; prompt on Liu]
parts: A farewell by Wang Wei is one of many Chinese poems to reference "white" examples of what objects, and claims they persist for all time?
This Chinese poet, whose "Farewell Song of the White Clouds" describes clouds floating over Chu, also wrote about gazing at the moon in "Quiet Night Thought".
In this author's story "The Poetry Cloud," Li Bai meets a god named Li Bai who builds a computer to write poetry. This Chinese sci-fi author wrote The Three-Body Problem.

answers: citric acid cycle [or TCA cycle, or Krebs cycle, or tricarboxylic acid cycle]
parts: Name this dicarboxylic acid, which can be synthesized by hydration of fumarate. Its namesake dehydrogenase converts it to oxaloacetate.
Malate is oxidized to oxaloacetate in this biochemical pathway, which takes acetyl-coA to produce NADH and FADH2 for use in the electron transport chain.

The citric acid cycle is regulated allosterically at three thermodynamically irreversible steps catalyzed by alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, isocitrate dehydrogenase, and what third enzyme? It catalyzes an aldol condensation.

answers: Frithiof [or Friðþjóf; accept Frithiof's Saga or Friðþjófs saga hins frœkna]
Baldr [or Baldur; accept Baldr's Dreams, Baldr's Dream, or Baldrs draumar]
parts: Name this Norwegian warrior who, in his namesake saga, returns from exile and succeeds Ingeborg's husband Ring to the throne. That saga was rendered into modern Swedish by Esaias Tegnér ("eh-SIGH-ahs teng-NAIR") in the 19th century.

Upon learning that Ring married Ingeborg, Frithiof burns down the sanctuary of this deity where he earlier visited Ingeborg. This deity's "dreams" are the subject of an Eddic poem, and his hall is Breidablik ("BRAY-thah-bleek").
Frithiof's Saga repeatedly mentions the "pale" realm of this goddess, who rules the bleak Norse underworld.

answers: Quintus Fabius Maximus Verrucosus [or Fabius Cunctator; accept Fabian strategy]
interior lines [prompt on lines of communication]
parts: Name this Carthaginian who won at Trebbia after invading Italy during the Second Punic War.
Hannibal's most effective opponent in Italy was this Roman, who avoided battles and used attrition to weaken Hannibal's army; he now lends his name to such strategies.

Rome stopped Carthaginian reinforcements by using this strategy to concentrate troops against Hasdrubal at the Battle of the Metaurus. In this strategy, an army exploits the namesake shorter routes inside its area of control to rapidly redeploy.

answers: Pitié-Salpêtrière University Hospital [or La Salpêtrière; prompt on hospitals or asylums; do NOT reveal this answer otherwise, but prompt on more specific answers mentioning the asylum that Gericault visited]
parts: Name this place. A woman known as the "hyena" of this place is depicted in one painting of a series that includes its artist's Portrait of a Kleptomaniac.
The aforementioned portrait of the "Hyena of Salpêtrière" was created by this artist. He depicted the remains of a shipwreck in The Raft of the Medusa.

A Clinical Lesson at the Salpêtrière was painted by André Brouillet ("bree-YAY"), a follower of this art style. Brouillet's mentor, Jean-Leon Gerome ("zheh-ROAM"), also followed this style, which stuck to rules outlined by art schools.
Name this early American novel in which the biloquist Carwin speaks in mysterious voices which eventually drive Theodore insane.
Wieland is an American example of this spooky fiction genre popularized in the 18th century by authors Horace Walpole and Anne Radcliffe.

Gothic elements in this American short story include its description of the dog Wolf, who "sneaked about with a gallows air," and its explanation that thundering in the mountains is caused by a group of ghosts.

answers: cosmic dust [or space dust or extraterrestrial dust or interplanetary dust; accept, but do not reveal, interstellar dust]
parts: Name this substance, which scatters sunlight to create the zodiacal light. It is the more dense of the two substances that causes extinction of astronomical radiation.
Dust comprises about 1% of the mass of this mostly gaseous substance, which occupies the space between two star systems in a galaxy.

A "dust solution" to the Einstein field equations describes a perfect fluid whose value for this quantity equals zero. The spacelike components of the main diagonal of the stress-energy tensor represent this quantity.
